column8: Eagles‚ÄØCrest, Knuckles Mountain Range ‚Äì Rustic Charm, Breathtaking Views & Local Warmth!!
column11: During our short familiarisation tour to Riverston and the Knuckles Mountain Range, we spent our last night at Eagles Crest and it truly is every bit the idyllic hideaway you would imagine. Nestled deep in the hills, it‚Äôs full of rustic charm, fresh mountain air, and stunning scenery. Many have described it as having a homely atmosphere, thoughtful touches, and warm hospitality, I couldn‚Äôt agree more. For those of us who live most of our lives in concrete jungles, finding a place like this is a rare gift. It is one of those places where you naturally disconnect from devices and distractions and breathe in some of the cleanest oxygen in the region. The peace is almost unreal. The heart and soul of the property is Sid, someone I have known for a long time. With decades of experience and deep knowledge of the Knuckles and its biodiversity, he brings something truly special to the place. His life stories and insights about the region could fill days just listening to him is an experience in itself. The property is hosted by the lovely couple "Kusume and Sira", and it feels more like a warm family home than a guest lodge. The accommodation is simple but comfortable and practical. Their home cooked meals were wholesome and satisfying, real Sri Lankan flavours served with care. The climate was just perfect, and the views, especially in the early morning, were absolutely magical. Eagles Crest is also an ideal base for exploring the area serene treks through tea plantations, misty forests, and remote village paths start right at your doorstep. The area is home to some incredible birdlife too, including endemics, something any nature lover will truly appreciate. What made the stay even more meaningful was knowing that by being here, we were supporting the local community. It is not just a place to stay, it is part of something bigger, helping small businesses, encouraging sustainable travel, and contributing to the well-being of the surrounding village. For Anyone Planning to Trek or Stay in the Area If you are planning to stay, hike, or explore the Knuckles region, it‚Äôs best to come prepared. The weather can be unpredictable, one minute it‚Äôs sunny, the next you are in the middle of mist and rain. Here‚Äôs a quick packing list that might help. Shorts & T-shirts Trainers or flip-flops Swim trunks Travel towel Insect repellent Poncho or raincoat (a must especially if hiking) Jumper for cooler evenings Flashlight / head torch Socks / leech socks Any essential medicines (the nearest town can be 30‚Äì40 minutes away) You don‚Äôt need fancy gear, but a bit of preparation goes a long way in making your time in this remote, beautiful region more comfortable and safe. üåø Leave No Trace ‚Äì Take only memories, leave only footprints. Please carry your trash back and help protect the beauty of Knuckles for future trekkers.

**A Journey to Remember: Trekking Kotaganga Falls in the Heart of Knuckles via Rangala** Nestled in the lush greenery and rugged terrain of the Knuckles Mountain Range, Kotaganga Falls is nothing short of a hidden gem waiting to be discovered. My journey to this secluded paradise was not just a trek through nature but a soulful voyage into the heart of one of Sri Lanka‚Äôs most spectacular landscapes and forest reserves in the Central Region. The adventure began with two of my guests from Colombo. I picked them up in my SUV, and we came to Knuckles Vila By Pila, who owns and manages two log cabins in the woods which is part of the Knuckles Massif. The early morning mist clung to the hills as we made our way through the entrance of an estate, Rangala Kalduriya Division, with our faithful native guide, Dinesh.  It was already raining, and I felt so relaxed and happy as I used to so many years back when I used to go on hikes in the rain. Rain makes me feel fresh and very much less tired. The climb was steep and challenging through the hardly visible nature trail yet incredibly rewarding. Along the way, the trail meandered through thick forests and verdant tea plantations, each turn unveiling a new facet of the region‚Äôs vibrant ecosystem. The sounds of chirping birds and the rustle of leaves underfoot became a soothing symphony. The sounds of birds and crickets added a touch of playful melody to the journey. As the trail ascended, cooler air and more dramatic views took over. Majestic peaks rose in the distance, their summits shrouded in a veil of rain clouds and slight mist. The sights were tranquil and the wonders of nature. After about four hours of trekking in the rain, the crescendo of the journey was in sight: Kotaganga Falls. The sight of the waterfall was breathtaking. Crystal-clear waters cascaded down a series of rocky steps, forming natural pools that shimmered invitingly in the semi-sunlight and partial rain. The air was filled with the gushing sound of the falls and the refreshing scent of mist and nature. The falls were a sanctuary, a place where time seemed to stand still, allowing one to bask in the glory of nature's grandeur. Taking a breather and some photos by the waterfall, I felt a profound sense of peace and fulfillment. The journey, with all its trials, had led to this moment of serene beauty. It was glorious. It was a reminder that sometimes, the most beautiful destinations are also the most challenging to reach, and it is the journey itself that shapes our experience. As we began our descent back to the lodge, I carried with me not just the memory of the stunning Kotaganga Falls, but also a renewed appreciation for the wonders that lie hidden within the Knuckles Range. This trek was a testament to the incredible beauty that nature offers, a journey that will remain etched in my heart for years to come. It's definitely an unforgettable experience! :) So here's a note to future travellers: Prepare Physically The trek to Kotaganga Falls can be quite demanding, so it's important to be in good physical condition and mindset. Regular walking, hiking, and stamina-building exercises can help you prepare for the journey. Dress and Gear Waterproof jackets or hoodies, leech socks for those who don't like the leech experience, warm pants if it's hiking in the rainy season, long-sleeve bush shirts or t-shirts to keep your hand from getting scratched from thorns or bushes, all-terrain hiking shoes or boots. Layering is key, as the weather can change quickly in this mountainous region. Pack light but make sure to include essentials such as: A waterproof backpack, plenty of water and snacks, a first aid kit, a flashlight or headlamp, and of course leech repellents like Dettol, salt, and soap mixed spray. Start Early To make the most of your day and avoid the sluggishness, start your trek early in the morning. Sunrise over the Knuckles can be a spectacular sight when not rainy, and the cooler morning temperatures will be more pleasant for hiking. Stay on Marked Trails, Hire a Guide The Knuckles Mountain Range is known for its dense forests and diverse wildlife. Stick to the marked trails to ensure you don‚Äôt get lost and to minimize your impact on the environment. Respect Wildlife and Nature This is most important. You‚Äôll come across various flora and fauna during your trek. Admire them from a distance and do not disturb their habitats. Take only photographs, and leave only footprints. Stay Hydrated and Energized Keep yourself well-hydrated and carry enough high-energy snacks to maintain your energy levels throughout the trek. Bananas, nuts, and energy bars are good options. Respect Local Communities Be mindful and respectful of the local communities you may encounter. Learn a few basic phrases in Sinhalese or Tamil as a gesture of goodwill, and be respectful of their customs and traditions. They will always support you when you need any help. Take Your Time The trek is as much about the journey as it is about the destination. Take breaks, soak in the views, and enjoy the serenity of nature. Don‚Äôt rush‚Äîtrekking is a chance to connect with nature and find inner peace. Keep at a moderate speed that you feel comfortable with. Make sure to get back before the evening mist sets in so that you are still able to see the paths. Stay Safe and Informed Check the weather forecast before you go, and be aware of any advisories or warnings. It‚Äôs also a good idea to inform someone about your trekking plans and estimated return time. Avoid extreme weather unless you feel you want to take a challenge. Leave No Trace Make sure to carry all your trash back with you and dispose of it properly. Preserve the natural beauty of the trail for future trekkers. Trekking to Kotaganga Falls is an incredible experience filled with breathtaking views, a rejuvination and a deep connection to nature. By following these tips, you can ensure a safe, enjoyable, and memorable adventure. Happy trekking, people!

In 2010 Sri Lanka was awarded its 8th UNESCO Heritage Site ‚Äì The Central Highlands because of its unique biodiversity. The Central Highlands Heritage site is actually a group of highlands comprising the Peak Wilderness Protected Area, Horton Plains and Knuckles Conservation Forest. The name Knuckles was designated by British Surveyors because of its resemblance to a clenched fist, but the Sinhala name is Dumbara Kanduvetiya (= Mist Laden Mountain Range). Knuckles is a very special isolated place comprising cloud forest, pygmy forest, the headwaters of several rivers, waterfalls, 34% of Sri Lanka‚Äôs trees, shrubs and herbs and a wildlife reserve with some endemic flora and fauna found nowhere else in Sri Lanka. The highest peak tops out at 1,904m. It is deservedly becoming a hotspot for eco-tourism, with bicycle a popular means of transport for visitors. Hiking and nature walks can also be organized for you.

The 3 hour hike consisted, from then on, of us checking each other every 2 mins for leeches. Some of the views were nice but we were not able to stop for long, or else we would be covered again. We were on a big group tour in Sri Lanka and had a free day in Kandy. Four of us decided to do a walk through the Knuckles ranges and struggled to find information about it online. We were put in touch with Nishantha (ph 0779188292) who is a local eco tourism guide. He lives in a small village on the outskirts of Kandy, where they only have phone reception (no email or website). He quoted us $50 usd pp, which we initially thought was expensive, but after finding only one other possible tour which was 18,000 lkr pp ($117 usd) we decided to do it. We are so glad we did! The price included hotel pickup from Kandy, a driver, a guide, lunch and a cup of local tea and the start and end. The guide was eco conscious (everything we took in, we took out) and well educated, having studied Ornithology at university. He was so enthusiastic and passionate and knowledgeable and spoke clear fluent english (bonus!). He could spot animals miles away and carried binoculars for us to use. He was also super patient while I took lots of photos. He reminded me of a Sri Lankan Crocodile Hunter (RIP Steve Irwin). We saw about 50 different bird species, two mongoose, macaques and butterflies, and walked across some incredible scenery, including rice paddy fields, small villages, tea plantations, through large boulders and had a swim in a waterfall. We spoke to locals from the Burnside area and Nishantha provided insight into working in tea plantations and life in rural villages. Lunch was provided, which was a very tasty curry and rice box which we ate at the waterfall. We opted to do the 10km walkthrough, which I would probably rate as a medium difficulty. The guide gave us a few options at the start as there are lots of different routes, and as we were walking, to see if we wanted to summit the mountain or go along the side. I would say to walk around the side because the view is still incredible and the path was a bit easier. I think summiting would have required some bushbashing. We were lucky with the weather. I think it would be a lot more challenging in rain as you walk through rice paddy fields which would probably turn to slush. There were lots of chisled steps out of rocks and walking up and down with the ridgeline in high humidity. Door to door was about 12 hours. I would 100% recommend this place and guide to anyone who wants an eco hike through real Sri Lanka. This will be my highlight of my holiday and will be an experience I remember forever. I strongly recommend it for people of medium/good fitness levels.

The walk started near the lake in Kandy & was through small villages (with friendly locals offering us tea, cake and fruit) and tea plantations. The route is relatively flat, with the elevation just rising towards the last 3-4km. When we arrived at our hotel we discovered there were hiking routes around nearby villages and tea plantations, as well as trips to mini world's end, waterfall tours, and the famous knuckles mountains (in Meemure). For most of these trips you hire a guide who picks you up in a tuktuk in the morning and takes you along the hiking route, pointing out animals, plants and areas of interest (this seemed to be from 30-50 dollars a day, depending on the trip). Or you can have a wander through some of the villages on your own. The air is very fresh, the views are beautifuland all of the people we encountered were so friendly. Would definitely advise to visit this seemingly untouched area of Sri Lanka.

We stayed overnight at Corbets Rest Guesthouse recently, its roughly about 2 1/2 to 3 hours drive from Kandy,  getting there is a bit of a winding, bumpy ride so make sure your vehicle is suitable for rough terrain. Rustic is fine but unless kept extremely clean is a bit depressing not to mention icky!..we went in March so the weather was fine and just a light sweater for the evenings is recommended as it is a bit chilly at night... there is electricity provided with the aid of a generator until about 10pm, so make sure you have your showers, lay out you PJs and have dinner before then! The dining area is below the rooms and probably not a good idea to take anyone who is a senior citizen unless they are extremely fit as the rough stone steps are quite steep and do take along a good torch oh and flat footwear. Dinner was delicious, Rice , chicken curry and about 5 veggie currys, bananas for dessert... saw about 2 staff members who were absolutely lovely and made you feel right at home... you can take your own alcohol, wine etc as I think they only have soft drinks... The best part of the evening was when the generator was shut down and they lit up candles, the dining area is made of stone as well with a verandah that runs alongside and it was lovely sitting out on the benches provided there and looking at the stars, and what stars they were! You know how in the city you see just a few stars because of the city lights? well, out there because of the complete and total darkness surrounding you the night skies are studded with thousands of stars which is absolutely beautiful, extremely quiet and peaceful as well, all we could hear was the stream below us and some insects having a chat! The morning we were able to have our first glimpse of the countryside surrounding us and it was absolutely beautiful, just surrounded by greenery.... breakfast was good, roti and katta sambol, toast, butter and preserves and eggs cooked to order plus tea or coffee... hiking is strenuous but fun in this area but be ready for the leeches!! there are hundreds of them everywhere... the only advice I can give you is keep your legs free from clothing from the knees down, so roll your pants up if they are long, I would say wear strong sandals if you are just strolling not proper hiking as the leeches are easily seen and can be flicked off before they do any damage, once they get in your socks  shoes or way higher you wont even know they are there! I must have flicked off about 50 in a one hour walk... you could carry a bottle of water mixed with soap and salt, and pour a few drops on them which makes them drop off... this part for us was the only not so enjoyable part of the trip but leeches come with the territory so theres nothing you can do about them...  they were there before us after all! So in a nutshell, if you like rustic living, simple yet tasty food and enjoy the great outdoors you will enjoy your stay at CR.

The Knuckles Mountain Range lies in central Sri Lanka, in the Districts of Matale and Kandy. The range takes its name from a series of recumbent folds and peaks in the west of the massif which resemble the knuckles of clenched fist when viewed from certain locations in the Kandy District. Whilst this name was assigned by early British surveyors, the Sinhalese residents have traditionally referred to the area as Dumbara Kanduvetiya meaning mist-laden mountain range (Cooray, 1984). The entire area is characterised by is often robed in thick layers of cloud. In addition to its aesthetic value the range is of great scientific interest. It is a climatic microcosm of the rest of Sri Lanka as the conditions of all the climatic zones in the country are exhibited in the massif. At higher elevations there is a series of isolated cloud forests, harbouring a variety of flora and fauna, some of which cannot be found anywhere else in the world.[citation needed] Although the range constitutes approximately 0.03% of the island‚Äôs total area it is home to a significantly higher proportion of the country‚Äôs biodiversity.

Knuckles mountain range consists of five peaks (as it looks like knuckles of the fist, called like that). There are about 36 prominent peaks in Knuckles massif and this is the 2nd highest peak out of them. There are two routes to start the trail. One from Bambarella side and other from Thangappuwa side. These two pathways join just below 1st peak. Both Bambarella and Thangappuwa can be approached by public transport. Few things to be kept in mind in this trekking; Bring enough water as  no water sources after some distance, protection from leeches and unpredictable weather. Most of the time hikers go upto 2nd peak (highest point-1848m) and sometimes they camp at there. I had an experince of climbing all five peaks in one day without camping. In that case you have to start the journey in early morning with light pack. This is a moderate strenous hike it takes about 6 hours to reach the fifth peak from trail head- Bambarella side. There is a clear foot pathway till 2nd peak and trail can be easily traced after this. If you are new for this environment, better have a local guide.

I signed up for a 3D2N trekking tour with SriLankatrekking.com with Ravi's team. It was just another traveller and I, with 2 guides. And I liked it that for the full 3 days at the mountain range, I only saw locals who live in the mountains, and NO other travellers.  (A good respite from the Well-beaten tracks in the country). The trek wasn't too challenging, so it's a good scenic walk with nature. You'd sleep in a campsite, with tents prepared for you. There are toilets and shower, but because it was cold at night, I skipped the cold shower. The camp master made good local food too, and were pretty helpful and friendly. Perhaps one thing that would bug you, is the leeches. They're everywhere in the trek, and you will DEFINITELY get them on your shoes. The guides will prepare Dettol solution to pour around your shoes, but it will not totally keep them away, so just be mentally prepared. You'd think it's a big deal when you see the first few leeches on your feet, but soon enough, you'd see so many that you'd sometimes just ignore haha! Well, that's really part of the experience. The summit climb might be a little tiring, but well, do it! Just be prepared for wet weather. Raining in the mountain range is pretty common, and weather changes can be very drastic and fast. I would recommend at least a 3D2N trek here at Knuckles. It's worth your time here.

We tried a one-day hiking excursion to the Knuckles this August.  I would say that the experience was mixed, but that mostly owes to us believing that we could just go there and do it. We spent 4 days her trekking through the jungle with professional guides. We carried everything that we needed (although porters could be hired) and stayed for two nights in tents at a basic campsite below a rock face and one night at Cobert's Rest Guest House. It was a fantastic experience with amazing views and basic living. The trekking itself was very challenging with rough trails through the jungle which in places were so steep we had to use ropes to climb them. I would advise taking some protection against leeches as these were a pain although had no ill after effects. It was an incredible achievement to finish the trek and I would love to do it again. I would also highly recommend Corbert's Rest Guesthouse which we stayed at one night. It was a very welcome break from sleeping in tents. We had own cabin set into the hill each with an amazing view of the Knuckles Range from just outside and the cabins themselves were very clean. There was no hot water, and electricity was just overnight but after nearly 3 weeks in Sri Lanka this was no problem. The staff were really hospitable and provided us with a dinner of Sri Lankan curry and rice and a breakfast of coconut rottis, fruit, toast, tea and jams all of which were delicious. I felt this trek and accommodation was the best experience I had in Sri Lanka.

The trip in the Knuckels was the most special part in our 16 day trip in Sri Lanka. We hired a local guide (a 67-year old man that wore slippers, a traditional skirt, a Russian like hat and had a bad knee). But he new the trails like no one else. We went on paths meant only for the villagers. The vegetation type changed every 10 minutes while climbing. It was amazing. It was the real jungle, just how you would imagine it. The trail was long, 10 hours, and in total we climbed 1,500meters in altitude. But it was worth every step. We stayed at Corbett's Rest. Beautiful location, friendly staff, excellent food (the best we had in Sri Lanka). However, the price is quite high for what they offer (120 $/night/room), considering we didn't have warm water and I couldn't take a shower after my long trip. All in all, I think these mountains are the best Sri Lanka can offer to a nature lover.

We went to the Knuckles Range on a day excursion from near Kandy. The trip was great, though it was very hard to find information about the area. Whether you have a day (like I did) or an entire 3 or 5 days, Knuckles Range is a MUST if you are in this part of Sri Lanka. A relatively easy hike up after about half an hour of rough road, you will find yourself surrounded by absolutely beautiful natural scenery: rolling tea plantations, lush green valleys and the gentle peaks of the mountain's 'knuckles' against a backdrop of clear blue sky (which I was lucky to have). The hike takes you through some tea growing fields as you follow the same walking paths trodden by local workers. Canopied walks under trees and brush followed by refreshing respites through the fresh water streams direct from the mountain source (and totally drinkable!). Depending on how far you go, you can see (or at least hear) the roar of distant waterfalls or otherwise take in the silence of being at the heart of nature, with just the buzzing of bees, dragonflies, birds and the wind for company. Camping is highly recommended. Bring a walking stick as some of the step climbing up can be steep (though they weren't many). And make sure to book a guide (US$80 to 100 including car and lunch for day trips), preferably one who has expert knowledge of the local fora and fauna of the area. It will make for a much more interesting journey!

My wife and I took a 1 day Knuckles Range trekking trip with a guide that our Guest House arranged.  His name is Kamura Sangha.  He is from Meemure, which is a village in the middle of the Knuckles Forest Reserve, so he was able to take us on a great trek (16 kms) in the Reserve around his village.  We were able to hike thru jungle, tea fields, rice paddies, and water falls where we had an opportunity to swim (but chose to nap instead).  Kumara was an excellent guide and was able to point out the different flora and fauna during our hike. The hike was at a good pace and for a good distance -- and the scenery was breath-taking!  The route we took was not the usual route that the other guides used.  Since this is where Kumara grew up and lives, he took on a circuit where we did not see another tourist for the entire day. The only downside was that it took 2 hours (in a tuk tuk) to get to the trekking starting point from Kandy.  Make sure you depart at the end of the day in enough time to make it back in daylight.  We took our time a bit and went to see an additional waterfall and ended up travelling in the dark.  Not the smartest thing to do in a tuk tuk. Lastly, there were leeches that you had to be on the look out for.  They were not the big,nasty looking ones that were used to bleed people with.  They are small, thin ones that are easy to spot and get rid of.  They really weren't an issue at all.  You just had to be diligent. All in all, it was a great day!  The hike and scenery made up for the tuk tuk travel.

We were on a visit to the Cultural Triangle when we discovered that our tour guide/driver Anil, who was organized for us by Kandy Cottage, was more than just a careful driver. We discovered that Anil is the owner of Srilanka Ecotrekking (http://www.srilankaecotrekking.com/) and accountant turned fervent biologist and nature lover with a passion for the Knuckles Mountain Range. A couple of days later Anil guided us on a one-day trek of his beloved mountains. We left Kandy just after 6 am and within the hour were on our way up into the unique cloud-cloaked and mist-laden micro environment that Anil calls the ‚Äòpigmy forest‚Äù. Our trek took us through tea plantations, forest clearings where henna was being grown, alongside the clearest of bubbling streams, through jungles, past amazing waterfalls, bamboo forests and into the stunted ‚Äòpigmy forest‚Äô. Through the mist we caught breath-taking views of majestic mountain peaks and were fortunate enough to see a mongoose, a civet, a porcupine and several birds whose names I do not remember. Anil is not only a lover of this area but is also a font of knowledge. He knows the flora and fauna and history of the area and is personable and friendly without being over-the-top. We did not see any deer, but may?? have caught a glimpse of a leopard. We had a picnic lunch at about 1,800 meters and after an hours rest made our way slowly back to the car where we were treated to a much welcomed cup of tea. Anil‚Äôs passion for this unique habitat was obvious. He spoke with passion of the over exploitation of this fragile system and the very visible effects of commercial cultivation of cardamoms and henna. Cardamom are being cultivated under the forest canopy and as Anil explained, the clearing of native undergrowth to undertake this activity is a major contributor to the degradation of the natural environment. We saw first-hand the evidence of invasive exotic species, particularly the ubiquitous lantana (Lantana Camara). The damage being caused by the clearing and burning of the forest to plant henna is also most obvious. My concern is however more for the wide sealed road that will bring bus loads of polluters. See it while it is still relative pristine. Like Everest Base Camp, this will not last.

Knuckles mountains - is a UNESCO world heritage site. It is about 1. 5 hours drive from Kandy. If you leave Colombo before the traffic builds up you can get there easily by 9.30 a m. If not you will end up getting there past noon. (To Deanston end) Make sure you know which side of Knuckles you are going to as the routeis  changes depending on whether it is Deanstone or Riverstone. Corbets View lodge is on Deanstone side and that is also the side to be at for a relatively easier trek to Meemure village. Knuckles is a good site for nature, fauna, flora enthusiasts and similarly interested photographers. It is also wonderful for trekkers and hikers as to here are many treks to choose from soft to hard and also depending on the time you have at hand. You can do easy 2-3 hour treks to half day, or day treks or even longer. There are campsite run by the Wild Life park authorities. You will need to reserve them in adance though. December and January are the rainy season and best avoided. Any other time is good. August/September brings the area strong winds and locals say - there is no winds as those winds! You will notice that most roofs have heavy objects loaded on them to keep the roof from flying away! This is also good for those who just want to relax and rejuvenate. If you hate to trek but just want to spend a quite peaceful holiday sipping tea and reading a book - still Knuckles moutainh as is a place to be.  The air quality is so good - after a couple of days your skin shows it! And dont forget to wake up early to see the sun rise- it is beautiful and a dream for photographers!

The Knuckles mountain range which is about an hours drive from Kandy is a largely unexplored area even though there are few folks that trek regularly. We were the only trekkers on this route with the exception of one other trekker we met on our way down. The upper range of the mountain has whats considered to be probably the only pygmy forest in the district. We commenced our climb at around 8.30am and got back to the starting point only around 7.30pm. It was raining during most of the day and we were not fortunate enough to reach the summit. Its a tough climb and you need to be physically fit and adequately equipped. You would also need to take a guide as the route is not marked and you could easily get lost in the myriad of pathways in the forest. There are also several starting points and you could recruit one of the locals from the village for a fee to guide you. However, it would be advisable to obtain some travel agents assistance if you're from overseas as the starting point for these treks are well off the beaten path. I would make this attempt again as rain thwarted us this time

We didnt climb the mountain but still thought it was amazing on the plateau. the one negative was that the climb up by the waterfalls was extremely difficult. We do alot of walking in Australia and I've never encountered a walk like this and found it almost too hard. The track had been cut through the jungle virtually straight up the incline instead of following the contours in places. this resulted in sheer walls to try and climb and it was very slippery with no hand holds as most of the plants gave way when you pulled them. This part of the track lasted a couple of hours and was very difficult so if you arent particularly fit it may be challenging. Mind you I'm not that fit and almost 50 so ..... The company did a great job, would recommend the trek for those of you who dont mind a hard climb and some leeches.
